NewsLines.HeadLine: UPDATE 1-Germany seen weakened by vote, U.S. ties in doubt

NewsLine.NewsLineText: GERMANY-ELECTION-FOREIGN (UPDATE 1):UPDATE 1-Germany seen weakened by vote, U.S. ties in doubt

body.p: (adds defence spending paragraph 5, EU enlargement 6, 18-19, Benes decrees 22-23)
By Paul Taylor, European Affairs Editor

BRUSSELS, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Germany emerged weakened from Sunday's general election and will need to move fast to repair relations with the United States damaged by Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's broadsides over Iraq, international analysts said.

Schroeder's coalition of Social Democrats and Greens clung to power with a sharply reduced majority despite gains for Edmund Stoiber's opposition conservatives. The government owed its survival to a strengthened showing by Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer's environmentalist Greens.

"This is not a good result for Germany, which needs a strong government to make difficult decisions, nor for Europe because we need a strong Germany as the engine of Europe," said Janusz Reiter, a former Polish ambassador to Berlin who is now president of the Centre for International Affairs in Warsaw.

Analysts said the slim majority would make it hard for the government to implement sorely needed labour market and welfare reforms to boost sluggish economic growth, which would involve taking on its own grassroots activists and trade unions.

It also makes any significant boost in low German military spending -- just 1.5 percent of gross domestic product -- look unlikely, sapping Berlin's contribution to efforts to build a common European defence and potentially reducing its influence.

But diplomats said the result improved the prospects of the European Union's historic eastward enlargement going ahead on time in December, since a re-elected German government would not need to start the crucial financial negotiations from scratch.

Reiter said Schroeder had taken a big risk with Germany's foreign relations by making virulent opposition to any U.S. military action against Iraq, even with United Nations backing, a major theme of his re-election campaign.
"Schroeder has made governing very, very difficult for himself. He let the genie out of the bottle and now it won't be easy for him to close the bottle again," Reiter said.
"POISONED ATMOSPHERE"

U.S. National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice said Schroeder's comments on Iraq and a comparison attributed to his justice minister between President George W. Bush and Hitler had "poisoned the atmosphere" in U.S.-German relations.

Schroeder announced on Monday that Justice Minister Herta Daeubler-Gmelin had informed party leaders she would not seek another term. She has denied having equated Bush's method of using a foreign threat to distract from domestic problems with Hitler's.
U.S. analysts said they expected Schroeder to act fast to limit the damage by announcing that Germany would take over the lead of the international peacekeeping operation in Afghanistan.

"They will move very quickly to reassure the allies by declaring as soon as possible their willingness to take over command in Afghanistan and probably to take on additional commitments in the Balkans," said William Drozdiak, director of the Transatlantic Centre in Brussels.
He said the Bush administration would make the chancellor pay a political price for his Iraq rhetoric. Schroeder would have to wait some time for an invitation to the White House.
However, Drozdiak said Fischer was trusted in Washington and would probably play the leading role in gradual reconciliation.

Philip Gordon, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution think-tank and former White House aide, said Schroeder had made Germany the odd man out in Europe with his Iraq stance, setting back the post-Cold War normalisation of Berlin's world role.
"Germany is a long way from that 'partnership in leadership' that George Bush Senior offered a decade ago," he said.
WEAKER IN EUROPE?

The German result, a week after Sweden re-elected a Social Democratic government, stopped a rightward drift in European politics that had seen conservatives win power in the last 18 months in Norway, Denmark, Italy, the Netherlands and France.

EU officials in Brussels and Denmark, which holds the bloc's presidency, expressed relief that there would be no political paralysis in Berlin or lengthy coalition negotiations, keeping the EU expansion process on track to conclude in December.

"Throughout this election, Chancellor Schroeder vigorously defended the enlargement project... We are convinced that by the necessary deadline, the end of October, Europe will have a common neogiating position on the financial package," European Commission spokesman Jean-Christophe Filori told reporters.
Up to 10 candidate countries are due to conclude entry talks in December, but negotiations on the financial terms have been on hold until Germany has a new government able to sign cheques.

Some candidates feared Stoiber would be meaner in funding enlargement and would seek to reopen the sensitive issue of the Benes decrees which expropriated ethnic Germans expelled from Czechoslovakia at the end of World War Two.
Czech analyst Rudolf Kucera, a political scientist at Charles University in Prague, said there might still be trouble.

"The German election result will not be a major boost for the EU talks because you cannot forget that the opposition, which raised the Benes decrees in its manifesto, will now have an even stronger position in the parliament," he told Reuters.

Neither French President Jacques Chirac, whose personal ties with the German leader are strained, nor British Prime Minister Tony Blair, at odds with Schroeder over economic liberalisation and Iraq, seem likely to be delighted with the result.

A revival of the Franco-German axis that used to drive EU integration seems uncertain, but some experts believe Berlin and Paris may agree to postpone an EU deadline for balancing their budgets to allow a less austere fiscal policy to revive growth.
